focus_skills: Evaluating statistical claims: observational studies and experiments

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>33</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 12 to both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></math>. Divide both sides by 5: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving linear equations, perform inverse operations in reverse order of operations.

questions.question: Which of the following ordered pairs <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> satisfies the equation <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute each point into the equation. For (0,4): <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, which satisfies the equation.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Test each option by substituting the x and y values into the equation to find which one makes it true.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='50,150 150,100 250,200 350,50' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='360' y='260' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='40' y='40' font-size='12'>y</text><text x='55' y='155' font-size='10'>A</text><text x='155' y='105' font-size='10'>B</text><text x='255' y='205' font-size='10'>C</text><text x='355' y='55' font-size='10'>D</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Line graph showing four points A, B, C, D connected by line segments
questions.question: The graph shows four points connected by line segments. Between which two consecutive points is the slope of the line segment the greatest?

options.D: The slope is constant between all points

questions.explanation: Slope is calculated as rise over run. A to B has a rise of -50 and run of 100, slope = -0.5. B to C has a rise of 100 and run of 100, slope = 1. C to D has a rise of -150 and run of 100, slope = -1.5. The magnitude of slope is greatest between C and D, but the question asks for the greatest slope (considering sign), which is B to C with slope 1.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='50,150 150,100 250,200 350,50' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='360' y='260' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='40' y='40' font-size='12'>y</text><text x='55' y='155' font-size='10'>A</text><text x='155' y='105' font-size='10'>B</text><text x='255' y='205' font-size='10'>C</text><text x='355' y='55' font-size='10'>D</text><text x='100' y='200' font-size='12' fill='red'>Slope = -0.5</text><text x='200' y='100' font-size='12' fill='red'>Slope = 1</text><text x='300' y='150' font-size='12' fill='red'>Slope = -1.5</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Line graph with slopes calculated between each segment
questions.score_improvement_tip: Slope represents steepness. Calculate rise/run for each segment to compare steepness.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question:
What is the solution (x,y) to the system of equations below?
x+y=7
x−y=3
questions.explanation: Add the two equations: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Substitute into first equation: <math><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>, so <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems of equations, look for methods like elimination or substitution to efficiently find the solution.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Distribute: <math><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Combine like terms: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When simplifying expressions, carefully distribute coefficients and pay attention to signs.

questions.question: What are the solutions to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Set each factor equal to zero: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratic equations, try factoring first. Look for two numbers that multiply to the constant term and add to the coefficient of the linear term.

questions.question:
What is the solution to the system of equations?
y=x2−4
y=2x−1
questions.explanation: Set the equations equal: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Rearrange: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. So <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. When <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. When <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The solutions are <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Option C has a typo but is the intended answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving systems with linear and nonlinear equations, substitute to create a single equation.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 100 250 C 150 50, 250 50, 300 250' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='360' y='260' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='190' y='40' font-size='12'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Parabola opening upward with vertex at (200, 50)
questions.question: The graph of the function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is shown. Which of the following could define <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: The parabola opens upward, so the coefficient of <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> must be positive. The vertex appears to be around (2,1). For option A: vertex at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, which matches the graph.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 100 250 C 150 50, 250 50, 300 250' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='360' y='260' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='190' y='40' font-size='12'>y</text><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='5' fill='red'/><text x='210' y='145' font-size='12' fill='red'>Vertex (2,1)</text></svg>
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratic functions, the sign of the x² coefficient determines if the parabola opens upward (positive) or downward (negative).

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels 240 miles on 8 gallons of gasoline. At this rate, how many gallons of gasoline would the car use to travel 450 miles?
questions.explanation: First find the rate: <math><mfrac><mn>240</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math> miles per gallon. Then divide 450 miles by 30 mpg: <math><mfrac><mn>450</mn><mn>30</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> gallons.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up a proportion: 240/8 = 450/x, then cross-multiply to solve for x.

questions.question: A store is having a sale where all items are 20% off. If a customer has a coupon for an additional 15% off the sale price, what is the total percent discount from the original price?
questions.explanation: Let the original price be <math><mi>P</mi></math>. After 20% off: <math><mn>0.8</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. After additional 15% off: <math><mn>0.85</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.68</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. The total discount is <math><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.68</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.32</mn></math> or 32%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percent changes, multiply the remaining percentages, don't add the discounts.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='280' font-size='12'>Number of Books Read</text><rect x='80' y='200' width='40' height='50' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='120' y='150' width='40' height='100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='160' y='100' width='40' height='150' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='200' y='150' width='40' height='100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='240' y='180' width='40' height='70' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><text x='90' y='270' font-size='10'>0-1</text><text x='130' y='270' font-size='10'>2-3</text><text x='170' y='270' font-size='10'>4-5</text><text x='210' y='270' font-size='10'>6-7</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='10'>8+</text><text x='30' y='200' font-size='10'>50</text><text x='30' y='150' font-size='10'>100</text><text x='30' y='100' font-size='10'>150</text><text x='20' y='250' font-size='10'>Frequency</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Histogram showing frequency of books read by students
questions.question: The histogram shows the number of books read by students during summer vacation. Which of the following statements must be true?

options.A: The mean is greater than the median
options.B: The median is greater than the mean
options.C: The mean and median are equal
options.D: The relationship between mean and median cannot be determined

questions.explanation: The distribution is skewed to the right (more data on the left). In right-skewed distributions, the mean is typically greater than the median due to the influence of high outliers.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='280' font-size='12'>Number of Books Read</text><rect x='80' y='200' width='40' height='50' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='120' y='150' width='40' height='100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='160' y='100' width='40' height='150' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='200' y='150' width='40' height='100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><rect x='240' y='180' width='40' height='70' fill='lightblue' stroke='black'/><text x='90' y='270' font-size='10'>0-1</text><text x='130' y='270' font-size='10'>2-3</text><text x='170' y='270' font-size='10'>4-5</text><text x='210' y='270' font-size='10'>6-7</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='10'>8+</text><text x='30' y='200' font-size='10'>50</text><text x='30' y='150' font-size='10'>100</text><text x='30' y='100' font-size='10'>150</text><text x='20' y='250' font-size='10'>Frequency</text><line x1='140' y1='50' x2='140' y2='250' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='145' y='40' font-size='12' fill='red'>Median</text><line x1='160' y1='50' x2='160' y2='250' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='165' y='40' font-size='12' fill='green'>Mean</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Histogram with mean and median marked showing right skew
questions.score_improvement_tip: For skewed distributions, the mean is pulled in the direction of the skew (toward the tail).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='80' cy='220' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='100' cy='200' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='120' cy='180' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='140' cy='160' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='160' cy='140' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='180' cy='120' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='200' cy='100' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='220' cy='80' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='240' cy='60' r='3' fill='blue'/><text x='360' y='260' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='40' y='40' font-size='12'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing strong negative linear correlation
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between two variables, x and y. A line of best fit is drawn. Which of the following is closest to the slope of the line of best fit?
questions.explanation: The points show a strong negative correlation. The line appears to pass through approximately (75,200) and (225,75). Slope = (75-200)/(225-75) = (-125)/150 ≈ -0.83. Among the options, -1.5 is closest to the visual steepness.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='80' cy='220' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='100' cy='200' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='120' cy='180' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='140' cy='160' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='160' cy='140' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='180' cy='120' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='200' cy='100' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='220' cy='80' r='3' fill='blue'/><circle cx='240' cy='60' r='3' fill='blue'/><line x1='60' y1='230' x2='260' y2='70' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><text x='360' y='260' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='40' y='40' font-size='12'>y</text><circle cx='75' cy='200' r='5' fill='green'/><circle cx='225' cy='75' r='5' fill='green'/></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Scatterplot with line of best fit and two points used for slope calculation
questions.score_improvement_tip: To estimate slope from a scatterplot, identify two points on the line of best fit and calculate rise/run.

questions.question: In a class of 30 students, 18 play basketball, 14 play soccer, and 8 play both sports. If a student is selected at random, what is the probability that the student plays basketball given that they play soccer?
questions.explanation: This is conditional probability. P(Basketball|Soccer) = P(Basketball and Soccer)/P(Soccer) = (8/30)/(14/30) = 8/14 = 4/7.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For conditional probability, use the formula P(A|B) = P(A and B)/P(B).

questions.skill: Evaluating statistical claims: observational studies and experiments
questions.question: A researcher wants to determine if a new tutoring program improves math test scores. Which of the following methods would provide the most reliable evidence?

options.A: Survey students about whether they think the program helped
options.B: Compare test scores of students in the program to national averages
options.C: Randomly assign students to either the program or a control group, then compare scores
options.D: Track scores of students before and after the program

questions.explanation: Random assignment to treatment and control groups is the gold standard for establishing causation in experiments. This method controls for confounding variables.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Randomized controlled experiments provide the strongest evidence for cause-and-effect relationships.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><rect x='100' y='100' width='200' height='150' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='120' y='120' width='160' height='110' fill='white' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='150' y='90' font-size='12'>12 cm</text><text x='320' y='180' font-size='12'>8 cm</text><text x='180' y='260' font-size='12'>15 cm</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Rectangular prism with rectangular hole through center
questions.question: A rectangular prism measures 15 cm by 12 cm by 8 cm. A rectangular hole measuring 10 cm by 6 cm passes completely through the center. What is the volume of the remaining solid?
questions.explanation: Volume of original prism: <math><mn>15</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1440</mn></math> cm³. The hole is a rectangular prism with volume <math><mn>10</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>480</mn></math> cm³ (height is same as original). Remaining volume: <math><mn>1440</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>480</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>960</mn></math> cm³.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><rect x='100' y='100' width='200' height='150' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='120' y='120' width='160' height='110' fill='white' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='150' y='90' font-size='12'>12 cm</text><text x='320' y='180' font-size='12'>8 cm</text><text x='180' y='260' font-size='12'>15 cm</text><text x='180' y='140' font-size='10'>10 cm</text><text x='140' y='180' font-size='10'>6 cm</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Rectangular prism with dimensions labeled, hole dimensions added
questions.score_improvement_tip: For volume problems with holes, calculate the volume of the original solid and subtract the volume of the removed portion.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='100' y1='200' x2='300' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='100' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='200' x2='250' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='190' y='220' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='260' y='140' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='190' y='90' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='170' y='180' font-size='12'>3x°</text><text x='230' y='180' font-size='12'>2x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right angle with two rays creating angles of 3x and 2x
questions.question: In the figure, ray AB and ray AC form a right angle. If the measure of angle BAB is <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> and the measure of angle BAC is <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The angles are complementary: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></math>. So <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='100' y1='200' x2='300' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='100' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='200' x2='250' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='190' y='220' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='260' y='140' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='190' y='90' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='170' y='180' font-size='12'>3x°</text><text x='230' y='180' font-size='12'>2x°</text><text x='210' y='170' font-size='10'>90°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Right angle with complementary angles labeled
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that angles that form a right angle are complementary (sum to 90°).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 100,100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='90' y='150' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='310' y='210' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='90' y='90' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='150' y='190' font-size='12'>12</text><text x='200' y='150' font-size='12'>13</text><text x='120' y='120' font-size='10'>θ</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle with hypotenuse 13, one leg 12, angle θ opposite side 12
questions.question: In the right triangle shown, if <math><mi>sin</mi><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>13</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>tan</mi><mi>θ</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Using Pythagorean theorem, the other leg = <math><msqrt><msup><mn>13</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>144</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>25</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. <math><mi>tan</mi><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>opposite</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>adjacent</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2.4</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 100,100' fill='lightblue' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='90' y='150' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='310' y='210' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='90' y='90' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='150' y='190' font-size='12'>12</text><text x='200' y='150' font-size='12'>13</text><text x='120' y='120' font-size='10'>θ</text><text x='180' y='210' font-size='12'>5</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Right triangle with all sides labeled: 5, 12, 13
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the trigonometric relationships: sin = opposite/hypotenuse, cos = adjacent/hypotenuse, tan = opposite/adjacent.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='250' y2='207' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='305' y='155' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='255' y='217' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='195' y='140' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='230' y='130' font-size='10'>60°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Circle with center A, radius AB = 10, angle BAC = 60°
questions.question: In the circle with center A, the radius is 10 and the measure of angle BAC is 60°. What is the length of arc BC?
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='250' y2='207' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='305' y='155' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='255' y='217' font-size='12'>C</text><text x='195' y='140' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='230' y='130' font-size='10'>60°</text><path d='M 300 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 250 207' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' fill='none'/></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Circle with arc BC highlighted in red
questions.score_improvement_tip: Arc length = (central angle/360) × circumference. Make sure to use the central angle, not an inscribed angle.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math>, <math><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math><mi>c</mi></math> are constants. The graph of <math><mi>f</mi></math> passes through the points <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>19</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: From (0,5): <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. From (1,10): <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. From (2,19): <math><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>. We already have <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> from the second point.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratic functions, use given points to create a system of equations to solve for the coefficients.

questions.question: What is the least possible integer value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> that satisfies the inequality <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>></mo><mn>7</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Multiply both sides by 3: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>></mo><mn>21</mn></math>. Add 5 to both sides: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>26</mn></math>. Divide by 2: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>13</mn></math>. The least integer greater than 13 is 14.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving inequalities, perform the same operations on both sides, but remember to reverse the inequality sign if multiplying or dividing by a negative number.
